To tackle our nation's burden of debt, tough decisions and careful solutions are required. But the solutions must include reforms to save and sustain the mandatory programs serving many vulnerable Americans.

The federal government does not have a revenue problem, it has a mandatory spending problem. In 1965, mandatory accounted for 34% of the budget. Last year, it made up more than two-thirds. By 2028, that figure is projected to reach 77%. https://twitter.com/TomColeOK04/status/1108172968037924864 …

In this week's column: @POTUS' recent budget proposal, America’s unsustainable mandatory spending problem and how my Bipartisan Social Security Commission Act could lead to solutions https://cole.house.gov/media-center/weekly-columns/ever-growing-debt-challenge …

#HR1 would disrupt and infringe upon the role states play in conducting their own elections. While some states are clearly more successful than others, it is alarming that Democrats want to force our 50 separate and unique states to operate under the same guidelines.

I was shocked and deeply saddened to learn of the sudden passing of Bill Burgess of Lawton. Oklahoma has lost a leader of exceptional vision, energy, ability and character. And I have lost a dear friend I will always remember and miss for all my days.

I was very sad to hear about the passing of former Congressman John Dingell, a legendary figure in the House who served his constituents for nearly 60 years. My thoughts and prayers are with John’s wife @RepDebDingell, their family and many loved ones.

I will neither participate in nor support efforts that use the tools of the House as a one-sided weapon to punish the president while ignoring the reckless rhetoric of so many of his Democratic critics. My full statement on H. Res. 489 ⬇️ https://cole.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/cole-statement-h-res-489 …
Americans who have different opinions are not racists. They are just Americans who have different opinions. Let’s respect one another more, disparage one another less and heal our land.
It is time to dial down the rhetoric on both sides and restore civility to the House floor and our national dialogue.
The result? Speaker Pelosi’s remarks of the floor were ruled out of order this afternoon, and the House was plunged into chaos.
In Rules Committee last night, I warned that if Democrats proceeded with their reckless resolution, it would be like "throwing gasoline on the fire." They went ahead anyway.
I am deeply disappointed in the president’s comments directed toward fellow Americans and members of Congress. Use of such language is inappropriate and demeans the office of the presidency.

I am disappointed that Democrats turned the historically bipartisan NDAA into a partisan exercise. Until today, I’ve never voted no on this annual bill because it’s always rightly affirmed support for our troops and the critical resources they need. https://cole.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/cole-statement-fy20-ndaa-house-vote …
